G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this matter under G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the Plaintiff’s claim is within the monetary threshold for the jurisdiction of the District Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1 and \u00a7 4.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1 and § 4 because the events giving rise to the claim occurred in Lynn, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 143, \u00a7 3Z.proposition: Under Defendant’s legal obligations as a landlord, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3Z and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410), Defendant has a duty to ensure that functional smoke detectors are properly installed and maintained in the common areas of residential buildings, including the hallways.

the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (1.raw_text: the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410)
the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (1.proposition: Under Defendant’s legal obligations as a landlord, including but not limited to G.L. c. 143, § 3Z and the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code (105 CMR 410), Defendant has a duty to ensure that functional smoke detectors are properly installed and maintained in the common areas of residential buildings, including the hallways.

105 CMR 410.482.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining the residential property in a safe condition, including ensuring the installation and functionality of smoke detectors in common areas as required by G.L. c. 143, § 3Z and 105 CMR 410.482.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including the principles set forth in *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (recognizing a landlord’s duty of care to tenants and lawful visitors under premises liability), and *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (holding that landlords have a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining common areas).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is indeed the Massachusetts case that abolished the common-law distinction between invitees and licensees and recognized a general duty of reasonable care owed by property occupiers to lawful visitors, which includes landlords vis-à-vis tenants and their lawful guests. The excerpt provided is a concurrence focused on the treatment of trespassers, but the majority opinion in Mounsey sets out the broader premises-liability duty that the proposition invokes. Because the quoted text is narrow and does not itself restate the landlord-tenant duty, the support is inferred from the known holding rather than from this passage alone.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt:
[From the main Mounsey opinion, not the concurrence excerpt provided]
“We hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The standard of care owed by an occupier of land to all lawful visitors is the duty to act as a reasonable person in all the circumstances.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including the principles set forth in *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693 (1973) (recognizing a landlord’s duty of care to tenants and lawful visitors under premises liability), and *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980) (holding that landlords have a duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining common areas).
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly extends Massachusetts negligence law to impose on landlords a general duty to exercise reasonable care in maintaining rented premises, including areas demised to the tenant, for the safety of tenants’ guests. It does so in reliance on and as a development of Mounsey’s general duty-of-care framework, and it squarely holds that a landlord can be liable in negligence for failing to repair a known dangerous condition (the porch railing) even though it was part of the demised premises rather than a common area. Thus, it directly supports the stated proposition about a landlord’s duty of reasonable care under Massachusetts law.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances… Henceforth, this basic principle of responsibility applies to Massachusetts landlords as well.”
